I.  THE PROPOSAL 
 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan to 
India for the Uttarakhand Integrated and Resilient Urban Development Project. The report also 
describes proposed technical assistance (TA) for Enhancing Climate Resilience in Uttarakhand 
Urban Development, and if the Board approves the proposed loan, I, acting under the authority 
delegated to me by the Board, approve the TA. 
 
2.  The project will support the Government of Uttarakhand in enhancing access to high-
quality and resilient water supply and sanitation (WSS) services in Dehradun and in upgrading 
sanitation facilities in Nainital. The project will apply a range of integrated, resilient, and innovative 
solutions: (i) centralized and decentralized sanitation systems and mobile toilets to enhance 
citywide inclusive sanitation (CWIS); (ii) citywide computerized maintenance and management 
systems (CMMSs) for WSS, based on smart technology and the first of its kind in India; and 
(iii) various measures to improve climate resilience. The project will also (i) promote behavioral 
change  toward  water  and  resource  savings,  and  better  hygiene  practices;  (ii)  empower 
communities for WSS-related jobs and foster entrepreneurial skills; and (iii) strengthen the 
institutional knowledge and capacity of state and local governments for integrated, sustainable, 
and climate-resilient urban development in Uttarakhand. 
 
II.  THE PROJECT 
 
A.  Rationale 
 
3.  Uttarakhand, part of the central Himalayas, is a young and fast-growing Indian state 
supported by manufacturing industries and tourism but confronted with significant climate change 
challenges. Its urban centers, as the homes of growing industries and gateways to tourism, 
attracted hill villagers who had suffered unstable horticultural conditions because of climate 
change and sought better opportunities for jobs and education. The rapid urbanization of climate-
vulnerable areas, and the difficulty in mobilizing sufficient human and financial resources led to 
significant gaps in the provision of basic infrastructure and services that also address climate 
change risks such as increasing water scarcity and extreme droughts and floods. The lack of high-
quality WSS places a disproportionate burden on the poor, estimated at 15.6% of the population.1 
It also greatly pressures women, the key players in household management and family health 
care, because they spend a lot of time and effort on fetching water and taking care of family 
members  sick  from  waterborne  diseases  and/or  poor  hygiene,  rather  than  participating  in 
economic activities. Given the widespread and prolonged impacts of the coronavirus disease 
(COVID-19) pandemic and aggravated climate risks, resilient WSS provision is the topmost 
priority; it is not only essential to human development but also critical to managing climate change 
and protecting people from future pandemic and epidemic diseases. The urban poor who are 
living in crowded neighborhoods under unhealthy hygiene conditions are particularly exposed to 
these challenges. 
 
4.  Dehradun, the capital of Uttarakhand, is the most populous city in the state. Its peri-urban 
areas grew at an unprecedented speed because of a huge influx of climate-induced urban 
migrants.  Compared  with  the  2011  census  data  of  569,578  people  living  in  61  wards  on 
64.6 square kilometers,2 Dehradun now covers 196.48 square kilometers (an increase of 300%) 
 
1  Government  of  Uttarakhand,  Department  of  Planning  and  Institute  for  Human  Development.  2018.  Human 
Development Report of the State of Uttarakhand. New Delhi.  
2  Census of India. 2011. District census handbook-Dehradun.

2 
and in 2018 had a population of 803,983 (an increase of 141%) living in 100 wards. Its boundaries 
were  redrawn  in  2018. 3 Previous  WSS  infrastructure  development  funded  by  the  Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) covered the pre-2018 city boundaries, and World Bank-funded support 
provided water supply in parts of the newly created wards. 4 Residents in the remaining areas 
either depend on unreliable water supply systems with significant leaks—receiving only 85 liters 
per capita per day during 3–4 hours of water service—or individual wells. Moreover, the water 
scarcity is worsening. The gap is even more significant when it comes to sanitation services—
Dehradun's newly added wards have no sewerage system and people rely on unregulated fecal 
sludge and septage management (FSSM). Untreated wastewater and fecal sludge are directly 
disposed of into rivers, causing greenhouse gas emissions and severe environmental and health 
risks.5 These risks can be aggravated during the rainy season, when the effluents get mixed with 
stormwater. Insufficient drainage systems and heavy encroachment of human settlement on the 
riverbeds constrain these rivers from properly performing their natural draining function and 
amplify the flooding impacts. Here, too, the situation is worsening as climate change leads to 
longer and more intense wet seasons. 
 
5.  Nainital, the judicial capital of Uttarakhand, is set in a valley of steep mountains around 
Nainital Lake. The estimated population in 2020 was about 60,000,6 or almost 50% more than the 
2011 census data of 41,377.7 Since Nainital is a highly popular hill station,8 it attracts on average 
about 72,650 daily visitors, of which 90% stay overnight.9 This huge floating population on top of 
an ever-increasing number of urban residents have caused severe water stress. Moreover, an 
observed depletion of groundwater, which got worse with climate change, and the deteriorating 
water  quality  of  Nainital  Lake  prompted  the  government  to  restrict  the  duration  of  water 
withdrawals from tube wells and lake water intake by the water authority in Nainital. The tap water 
service hours were also reduced,10 despite the water supply infrastructure developments funded 
by ADB (footnote 4). The leaks in the aging trunk sewer (built in 1940) and insufficient capacity of 
the existing sewage treatment plant (STP) led to sewer gases being emitted into the atmosphere 
and accelerated water pollution, making it difficult to rely on surface water as a climate-adaptive 
source of water supply. Replacing the leaking trunk sewer and the malfunctioning STP and 
expanding the sewerage treatment capacity in Nainital are urgent tasks if the city and its WSS 
systems are to be sustainable and climate-resilient. 
 
6.  The project incorporates lessons from ADB-financed projects in Uttarakhand11 and other 
states in India—e.g., that (i) reliable WSS system development with household connections and

approach should be considered to make sanitation solutions cost-effective, wider-reaching, and 
less water-dependent; (iii) institutional arrangement and stakeholder coordination should be 
strengthened to ensure timely project implementation; (iv) the allocation of implementation time 
and private sector involvement should factor in the nature of works, geographical conditions, and 
the  capacity  of  implementing  agencies  and  urban  local  bodies  (ULBs);  (v)  private  sector

(UUSDA), ULBs, Uttarakhand Peyjal Nigam (UJN), and Uttarakhand Jal Sansthan (UJS);12 and 
(vii) the use of smart technologies should be promoted to improve WSS-related operational 
efficiency, system maintenance, and asset management. 
 
7.  The project is aligned with (i) pillars 2 and 3 of ADB’s country partnership strategy for 
India, 2018–2022 and the mitigation of negative climate change impacts;13 (ii) the Sustainable 
Development Goals (SDGs);14 and (iii) ADB’s Strategy 2030, particularly the operational priorities 
of  (a)  making  cities  more  livable;  (b)  strengthening  governance  and  institutional  capacity; 
(c) accelerating progress in gender equality; (d) tackling climate change, building climate and 
disaster resilience, and enhancing environmental sustainability; and (e) addressing remaining 
poverty and reducing inequality. 
 
B.  Project Description 
 
8.  The project is aligned with the following impacts: (i) universal and equitable access to safe 
and affordable drinking water improved, and (ii) access to adequate and equitable sanitation and 
hygiene  enhanced to  end  open  defecation.15 The  project  will  have the  following  outcome: 
reliability and efficiency of resilient WSS services in Dehradun and Nainital enhanced.16 The 
project has four outputs. 
 
9.  Output 1: Resilient water supply system and service in Dehradun improved. The 
project will construct about 136 kilometers (km) of water supply pipe systems in newly added 
wards in South Dehradun to replace leaking networks. This will ensure reliable and quality 24-7 
water supply services of a standard 135 liters per capita per day. By 2028, the project will also 
provide water meters to about 5,400 household connections, enabling efficient water use and 
volumetric billing. This will reduce nonrevenue water (NRW) in the project area from 45%–50% 
to no more than 25%, which is better than the state's performance standard.17 Such resilient water

supply systems will lessen the water stress in Dehradun and benefit about 40,000 people, 
including about 4,000 urban poor and vulnerable people, by 2028. 
 
10.  Output 2: Integrated and resilient sanitation systems and drainage established in 
Dehradun and Nainital. The project will construct (i) two STPs with a total treatment capacity of 
29 million liters per day (MLD); (ii) 256 km of enclosed underground sewer networks to stop 
greenhouse gas emissions from untreated wastewater; (iii) 117 km of enhanced stormwater 
drainage  networks  that  factor  in  potential  climate  risks;  and  (iv)  17,410  household  sewer 
connections, all in Dehradun. This will benefit about 138,000 residents, including 15,000 urban 
poor and vulnerable people by 2028. The project will include FSSM for the households that are 
not connected to sewer networks within the project areas. Combining these two, the project will 
establish cost-effective integrated CWIS solutions in Dehradun that are also climate friendly. Once 
households are connected to the new centralized sewer system, they will no longer need to use 
soak pits. After cleaning these soak pits and connecting them to the rainwater capturing system, 
they can be reused as groundwater recharge pits—an innovative solution geared to climate 
adaptation and the circular economy. In Nainital, where the sewerage system has 100% coverage 
and benefits about 154,000 people, the project will (i) replace about 4 km of aging and leaking 
trunk and outfall sewers; (ii) construct an STP with a treatment capacity of 17 MLD and advanced 
moving bed biofilm reactor technology to replace an old STP; and (iii) build five additional 
prefabricated compact STPs that meet the challenges of a flood-prone steep hilly town with limited 
land space, each with a capacity of at least 20 kiloliters per day and the same moving bed biofilm 
reactor technology; these STPs are also equipped for the reuse of treated wastewater, which will 
lessen water stress in Nainital. 
 
11.  Aiming to increase access to quality and affordable sanitation and hygiene services for 
residents and visitors, the project will pilot-test 20 mobile toilets with gender-sensitive and 
inclusive design features.18 Old buses no longer suitable for the transport of people will be 
converted into mobile toilets and placed in urban areas that lack public toilets.19 The deployment 
of these mobile toilets will prevent open urination and/or defection, stimulate behavioral change 
toward healthy sanitation practices, and hence contribute to positive health impacts. Mobile toilets 
that fit into limited land space in Uttarakhand's urban centers are also innovative and climate-
adaptive solutions during flood events. 
 
12.  Output 3: Computerized maintenance and management systems for water and 
sanitation developed and implemented in Dehradun and Nainital. To advance the O&M 
performance and the management of WSS assets in Dehradun and Nainital, the project will 
procure, install, and implement four citywide CMMSs for WSS schemes. Using the internet of 
things, this information and communication technology-based platform will be integrated with 
supervisory control and data acquisition (SCADA) and a geographic information system (GIS) to 
provide  real-time  data  and  information.  The  platform  can  perform  various  tasks  such  as 
(i) recording and presenting the operational status; (ii) scheduling and tracking inspections; 
(iii) planning, implementing, and reporting the results of preventive maintenance; (iv) managing 
fixed assets across multiple sites; (v) managing inventory, work orders, and contracts; and 
(vi) providing customer services, not least by establishing a consumer data management system

toilets will have enough space for women's hygiene needs, their babies and children, and safe and comfortable 
breast feeding.

platforms that are under development or will be developed.21 
 
13.  Output 4: Institutional capacity and knowledge strengthened. The project will  (i) 
develop robust WSS O&M manuals that are in line with the national WSS manuals22 but tailored 
to the project cities' WSS system, governance structure, and conditions and needs; (ii) provide 
training to UUSDA, UJN, UJS, and project ULBs on the WSS O&M manuals and the CMMSs; 
(iii) carry out community awareness, participation, and behavioral change programs that promote 
water conservation; sound public health and hygiene practices; waste reduction; and safe, clean, 
and healthy community environments; (iv) implement the gender equality and social inclusion 
(GESI) action plan, including the stipend-based women internship program at UUSDA (para. 28); 
(v) develop  climate  adaptation  support  tools  in  Dehradun  and  Nainital  (para.  19);  and 
(vi) strengthen the institutional capacities of UUSDA, UJN, UJS, and project ULBs for sustainable 
urban infrastructure and services, including WSS tariff restructuring, to manage sustainable,23 
green, and resilient urban planning for livable and prosperous cities, integrated watershed and 
water management, ecosystem-based adaptation measures,24 and GESI issues in urban systems 
and services. 
 
C.  Value Added by ADB 
 
14.  ADB provided an additional grant to pilot-test intelligent water leak management systems 
using (i) innovative sensor-based water leak detection technologies, and (ii) a leak analysis and 
data  management  information  and  communication  technology  platform  to  advance  NRW 
management (footnote 17). To improve CWIS in Uttarakhand, ADB (i) advised an addition of a 
co-treatment unit to a proposed STP in collaboration with the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation, 
and (ii) provided a TA grant to investigate the FSSM service level and performance of private 
FSSM service operators.25 ADB ensures the provision of both household water and sewer 
connections as a part of civil works. Besides applying SCADA- and GIS-based asset mapping for 
WSS for the first time in Uttarakhand (para. 12), the project also introduces for the first time 
advanced CMMS solutions to India that will modernize WSS O&M and services with optimized 
efficiency and quality.26 Responding to the state government’s growing concern about climate

change and associated risks, the attached TA will (i) carry out thorough scientific assessments 
and modeling; (ii) apply ecosystem-based adaptation measures (footnote 24); and (iii) develop

III.  ATTACHED TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
19.  The state of Uttarakhand is part of the central Himalayas, comprising numerous glaciers 
and perennial rivers, and providing water to large parts of the country. Yet, severe water runoff, 
increasing water demand, extreme floods and droughts, and aggravated water pollution led to 
water scarcity, particularly in urban centers. Faced with more frequent and extensive impacts from 
climate-induced  hazards,  like  the  2021  snow-burst  flood  in  the  Chamoli  district,  the  state 
government  requested  ADB’s  support  to  tackle  the  complex  climate-  and  human-induced 
problems and to find solutions to enhance resilience effectively. Thus, the attached TA will include 
(i) situation analysis, scientific studies, and modeling for various scenarios in Dehradun and 
Nainital watersheds; (ii) the development of interactive, map-based climate adaptation support 
tools that provide information on flood- and other hazard-prone zones, various climate-resilient 
solutions and associated costs, and measures to improve resilience; (iii) the formulation of a 
framework for Uttarakhand's climate resilience, including selection and design of priority resilient 
investment  measures  in  upstream  and  downstream  urban  areas;  and (iv) capacity  building 
activities for climate-resilient planning and development. The TA is estimated to cost $1,100,000, 
of which (i) $250,000 will be financed on a grant basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special 
Fund (TASF-other sources); and (ii) $750,000 will be financed on a grant basis by the Climate 
Change Fund. The government will provide counterpart support in the form of staff, office space, 
and other in-kind contributions, equivalent to $100,000. 
 
IV.  DUE DILIGENCE 
 
A.  Technical 
 
20.  The project is technically robust based on a comprehensive review of detailed project 
reports, bidding documents, cost estimates, relevant documents, and virtual site investigations. 
The subprojects, i.e., the physical assets to be built or installed under outputs 1–3, meet the 
technical criteria of (i) rationale and relevance, benefits, and ease of implementation and O&M; 
(ii) comparison with technical alternatives; (iii) cost-effectiveness; (iv) optimal resource efficiency; 
(v) maximum inclusive beneficiary coverage; and (vi) minimum adverse environmental, social,

9 
heritage, and climate change impacts. The viability of connecting new and existing pipe networks 
and facilities for smooth system integration is confirmed. Intelligent O&M and asset management, 
CWIS components, advanced sewage treatment technologies, buses converted into mobile 
toilets, soak pit reutilization, and other climate-resilient measures are key project features. 
 
B.  Economic and Financial Viability 
 
21.  Economic analysis. The economic analysis evaluated the economic feasibility of the 
subprojects to be implemented in two project cities. The estimated combined economic internal 
rate of return is 11.1% (17.2% for the Dehradun water supply subproject, 9.5% for the Dehradun 
sanitation subproject, and 10.7% for the Nainital sewerage subproject), which is higher than the 
economic opportunity cost of capital estimated at 9.0%, which indicates significant economic 
returns. The sensitivity analysis revealed that the overall results are satisfactory, except for the 
scenarios of an increase in capital costs and a decrease in benefits, and the combined worst-
case scenario for the sanitation and sewerage subprojects in Dehradun and Nainital.  The 
subprojects' economic viability is expected to further increase if unquantifiable benefits such as 
environmental improvements are included in the analysis. The poverty impact ratio is estimated 
at 21.0% for Dehradun water supply, 27.8% for Dehradun sanitation, and 40.6% for Nainital 
sewerage. Based on the currently defined urban people living below the poverty line (12.4% in 
Dehradun, 28.8% in Nainital and 10.5% in Uttarakhand State),31 the subprojects are expected to 
considerably benefit the poor. 
 
22.  Financial analysis. The financial analysis was conducted for all three subprojects. The 
water subproject in Dehradun is likely to generate adequate revenues for full O&M cost recovery 
with regular tariff revisions. The wastewater subprojects in Dehradun and Nainital are unlikely to 
generate adequate revenues for full O&M cost recovery without substantial tariff revisions, posing 
risks to the project’s sustainability. The state government has enabled the revision of tariffs for 
O&M cost recovery, so the financial sustainability risk is moderate. The state government is 
committed to ensuring gap funding for the O&M of subprojects through budgetary allocations to 
ULBs. ULBs will aim to achieve full O&M cost recovery by (i) adopting a tariff structure more in 
line with costs, (ii) reducing NRW and operational costs, and (iii) improving billing and collection 
efficiency. The state government is already implementing reforms in ULBs aimed at augmenting 
their own-source revenue and strengthening the financial management system through adoption 
of better corporate governance structures and a monitoring framework (footnote 23).  
 
C.  Sustainability 
 
23.  To ensure the project's sustainability, the state government will implement and monitor 
the  progress  of  institutional  and  financial  reforms,  ensuring  O&M  recovery  through  tariff 
adjustment and O&M gap funding if an O&M shortfall occurs. In the short-term, 5-year O&M 
contracts will apply to all subprojects, and the state government has ensured adequate funding 
to UUSDA to make payments to O&M contractors. Longer term, the state government, through 
UDD, will ensure that (i) UUSDA will hand over the subprojects to the respective ULBs after 
completion of the 5-year O&M period, (ii) ULBs are legally empowered to set and collect water 
and wastewater tariffs, and (iii) ULBs maintain and operate the assets through own-source 
revenues in line with the progress of implementation of the 74th Constitutional Amendment Act 
(footnotes 12 and 30).

D.  Governance 
 
24.  Financial management. The financial management assessment of UUSDA was carried 
out in accordance with ADB guidelines.32 The assessed pre-mitigation financial management risk 
is  substantial.  ADB  and  the  state  government  discussed  enhanced  financial  management 
arrangements in detail and agreed on a financial management action plan to mitigate the identified 
risks  and  ensure  compliance  with  ADB’s  financial  management  requirements  throughout 
implementation. The action plan is included in the PAM (footnote 29). 
 
25.  Procurement. The overall procurement risk is moderate. Strategic procurement planning 
ensures that fit-for-purpose approaches are developed to achieve value for money while meeting 
development objectives. The procurement strategy enhances value for money by making sure 
that (i) financial bid evaluation includes elements of lifecycle cost evaluation that consider the cost 
of consumables, (ii) private sector involvement through a 5-year design–build–operate (DBO) 
contract  will  strengthen  the  institutional  capacity  of  asset  owners  and  improve  financial 
sustainability,  and  (iii)  early  completion  bonus  payments  to  DBO  contractors  will  expedite 
construction  completion.  All  procurement  of  goods,  works,  and  consulting  services  will  be 
undertaken in accordance with the ADB Procurement Policy (2017, as amended from time to 
time) and Procurement Regulations for ADB Borrowers (2017, as amended from time to time). 
 
26.  ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) was explained to and discussed 
with the state government, UDD, UUSDA, and the PMU. The specific policy requirements and 
supplementary measures are described in the PAM (footnote 29). 
 
E.  Poverty, Social, and Gender 
 
27.  The project will support SDGs 1, 5, 6, 11, and 13 (footnote 14). Pro-poor design features 
include (i) providing free house sewer and water supply connections to poor and vulnerable 
households;  (ii)  improving  sanitation  services  in  low-lying  and/or  peri-urban  areas  without 
sewerage facilities by establishing a FSSM system; and (iii) conducting awareness and behavioral 
change campaigns on water and resource conservation, sanitation, and hygiene for project 
beneficiaries, including the poor. Also, the poor will benefit from employment opportunities during 
project implementation. 
 
28.  The project is categorized effective gender mainstreaming. A GESI action plan was 
prepared  based  on  the  project-specific  gender  and  social  analysis.33 Key  features  include 
(i) improved access for 90% of households living below the poverty line, or belonging to scheduled 
tribes, scheduled castes, or other backward castes; (ii) skills training for community women to 
encourage their participation in WSS O&M; (iii) training of female staff and ward members on 
CMMS, sustainable and smart WSS management, and GESI issues in urban systems and 
services; and (iv) a stipend-based internship program for women. A community awareness and 
public participation agency will be engaged to support the PMU and the project implementation 
units in implementing the GESI action plan and the project grievance redress mechanism.

F.  Safeguards 
 
29.  In compliance with ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement (2009), the project’s safeguard 
categories are as follows.34 
 
30.  Environment (category B). All the subprojects are in urban areas and do not involve 
forest, environmentally sensitive or protected areas, or physical cultural resources. Six draft initial 
environmental examinations (IEEs), including environmental management plans (EMPs), were 
prepared and attached to all the works bid packages based on preliminary designs, confirming no 
significant  adverse  environmental  impacts  that  are  irreversible,  diverse,  or  unprecedented. 
Potential  environmental  impacts  are  site-specific,  short-term,  and  can  be  mitigated  and/or 
minimized to acceptable levels through design considerations and EMP measures, including a 
COVID-19-related health and safety plan. The state government will obtain regulatory consents 
and permissions, as required, before contracts are awarded or construction activities begin. Public 
consultations were conducted in compliance with preventive COVID-19 measures. All the draft 
IEEs were disclosed on the websites of ADB and the state government and will be updated during 
detailed design and submitted for ADB’s concurrence and disclosure. The state government 
committed to have appropriate institutional arrangements and human resources in place, and to 
carry out capacity building activities to manage environmental safeguards and implement the 
EMPs and the project-specific grievance redress mechanism, as detailed in the PAM (footnote 
29) and the IEEs. All works contracts will contain safeguard provisions. No works will start before 
the state government has cleared construction-site-specific EMPs with COVID-19-related health 
and safety plans, and ascertained regulatory compliance, and ADB has cleared the updated IEEs. 
The state government will prepare and disclose semiannual environmental monitoring reports 
during construction and annual reports during operation. 
 
31.  Involuntary resettlement (category B). Six draft resettlement plans were prepared and 
attached to all the six works bid packages in accordance with ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement 
and government laws. No land acquisition, physical displacement, or permanent economic 
impacts are anticipated. It is expected that WSS pipe laying and the ensuing road restoration will 
cause temporary income loss for 88 roadside shop owners (with 465 family members), of whom 
32  are  vulnerable  people.  The  measures  in  the  draft  resettlement  plan  and  monitoring 
arrangements are adequate for mitigating the identified impacts. The draft resettlement plans will 
form  part  of  the  contract  documents,  updated  during  detailed  design  based  on  detailed 
measurement and census surveys, and submitted to ADB for review before construction works 
start. The draft and the updated resettlement plans are and will be disclosed to project-affected 
persons and on ADB and project websites. The grievance redress committee will have civil society 
representation and be gender inclusive. The state government has demonstrated the capacity to 
manage the social safeguards of ADB-financed loans (footnote 4). The proposed capacity building 
programs as well as project consultants will further bolster the management of involuntary 
resettlement  impacts.  The  state  government  will  prepare  and  disclose  semiannual  social 
monitoring reports during implementation. 
 
32.  Indigenous peoples (category C). Scheduled tribes reside in the municipal and adjoining 
urban outgrowth areas of Dehradun (0.76% of the population) and Nainital (0.68%). They are 
assimilated in urban society in both cases. It is expected that one person of a scheduled tribe will 
suffer temporary income loss because of the project (para. 31).  The project will not impact 
indigenous peoples’ groups because it does not involve direct or indirect impacts on their dignity,

2023–June 2028). 
4.7 Complete gender equality and social inclusion action plan (June 2023–June 2028). 
Project Management Activities 
Establish and make operational project management unit and project implementation units. 
Mobilize project management and design supervision consultant. 
Conduct surveys for baseline data and information collection.
